awd_titl_txt: RIDIR: IPUMS-Terra: Global Population and Agricultural Data
awd_abstract_narration:
IPUMS Terra integrates, preserves, and disseminates data describing characteristics of the human population and the environment. By assembling a rich collection of the world's population and agricultural census data and incorporating it into the IPUMS Terra infrastructure, this project will enhance scientific understanding of critical policy-related issues such as food and water security, migration, socioeconomic and environmental vulnerability, and the effects of social and environmental policy on economic development, well-being, and long-run sustainability. IPUMS Terra and the data added under this project will be used by academic researchers from a wide range of disciplines, including ecologists, sociologists, economists, agronomists, and many others, to investigate important questions related to human-environment interactions. The findings of these researchers, along with direct use of the data by journalists, governmental officials, non-governmental organizations, and educators, will make important contributions to education, public understanding, and informed policy decisions.

This project will incorporate data from over 1,000 population and agricultural censuses into IPUMS Terra. IPUMS Terra technology makes data from different formats commonly used by different scientific disciplines easily interoperable. The massive collections of area-level population and agricultural census tables incorporated under this project will address important gaps in the existing IPUMS Terra system. The new population data cover nearly every country in the world, making IPUMS Terra a truly global resource. In addition, aggregate data tables combine extensive topical depth with fine geographic detail, enabling detailed study of population and agricultural characteristics. Finally, the new agricultural census data will complement both population data and land use and land cover data already in IPUMS Terra, facilitating comprehensive examinations of human-environment interactions, food production systems, and socioeconomic and environmental vulnerability. This project has four main objectives: 1) Develop data manipulation tools to transform diversely formatted published tables into a standardized structure. 2) Extend metadata and workflow management tools to capture metadata describing the contents and provenance of each data element. 3) Process, document, and ingest tens of thousands of tables into the IPUMS Terra infrastructure. 4) Conduct outreach to the scientific community as well as students, policy makers, journalists, and the general public.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences
org_div_long_name: Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: REGENTS OF THE UNIVERSITY OF MINNESOTA

por.por_cntn:
This RIDIR award funded the initial development of the IPUMS International Historical Geographic Information System (IHGIS) data collection and data access system. IHGIS collects data tables from population and housing censuses and agricultural censuses from countries around the world. These data tables have been published by national statistical agencies, most often contained in PDF documents posted on the agencies’ websites. IHGIS also incorporates summaries of individual-level data from our sister project, IPUMS International, tabulated for geographic units (such as states, districts, and municipalities). As originally published, the data are difficult for researchers to use because they are scattered across hundreds of websites, are not in file formats useful for data analysis software, and use a wide variety of table structures. 

IHGIS unleashes the potential of these data. It has developed software and workflows to extract tables from the published documents, transform them into a consistent structure, and provide them to researchers in data files ready for use in statistical and geographical analysis software packages. IHGIS also creates geographic data files for the boundaries of the geographic units described in the data tables. The tables and geographic files are easy to link in order to make maps and conduct spatial analysis. The data are accessible through an easy-to-use interface on the IHGIS website at https://ihgis.ipums.org/. The IHGIS collection currently includes over 14,000 tables from 338 censuses in 109 countries. The collection will continue to grow as work on IHGIS continues.

Population and housing and agricultural census data are foundational for research and planning in many fields. Population and housing censuses provide rich data on demographics, education, employment, and living conditions, while agricultural censuses provide data on farming inputs, practices, and productivity. By providing easy access to these data from around the world, IHGIS enables research on topics such as human-environment interactions and vulnerabilities, population aging, economic development, and changes in agricultural practices. Policy makers can use the knowledge gained from this research to develop better policies addressing critical issues such as migration, food security, and climate adaptation. IHGIS helps promote the progress of science, and provides fundamental data that support research and policy that helps advance national health, prosperity, security, and welfare in a deeply interconnected world.

 


Last Modified: 06/21/2023
Modified by: Steven M Manson
